title: Abbey Park (Grimsby)
text:
Abbey Park was a <a href="association%20football">football</a> stadium in <a href="Grimsby">Grimsby</a>, <a href="Lincolnshire">Lincolnshire</a>, England. It was the home ground of <a href="Grimsby%20Town%20F.C.">Grimsby Town</a> between 1889 and 1899.
History.
Abbey Park was built as a replacement for Grimsby's previous ground, Clee Park. It consisted of a main seated stand on the northern touchline of the pitch and a raised bank on the southern touchline. Behind the eastern end of the pitch there was a 300-seat stand moved from Clee Park, alongside an 800-capacity terrace. The dressing rooms were located in the south-east corner of the ground.
The ground was opened on 30 August 1889 with a friendly match against <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Brom</a>, which Grimsby won 6–1. Grimsby became founder members of the <a href="Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Football League Second Division</a> in 1892, and the first League game at Abbey Park on 3 September 1892 saw Grimsby beat <a href="Northwich%20Victoria%20F.C.">Northwich Victoria</a> 2–1 in front of 5,000 spectators.
The record attendance of 10,000 was set on 26 December 1896 for a match against <a href="Newcastle%20United%20F.C.">Newcastle United</a> (with Grimsby winning 3–2) and equalled for an 8 April 1897 game against <a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Woolwich Arsenal</a>, a game which Grimsby won 3–1. In 1899 Grimsby moved to <a href="Blundell%20Park">Blundell Park</a>; the final match at Abbey Park was played against <a href="Darwen%20F.C.">Darwen</a> on 15 April 1899, with the 9–2 victory also being the ground's record home win.
A housing development was later built on the site.
